entry.title: Re: sap business one service layer -Filtering field from...
entry.content:
{
"QueryPath": "$crossjoin(FixedAssets,FixedAssets/DepreciationLines)",
"QueryOption": "$expand=FixedAssets($select=DocEntry,DocNum,DocStatus,RefDate),FixedAssets/DepreciationLines($select=DocEntry,AssetCode,DepreciationAmount)&$filter=FixedAssets/DocEntry eq FixedAssets/DepreciationLines/DocEntry"
}

"value": "Invalid query objects."  

My Questions:

  1. Is ODRN/DRN2 the correct way to reference the line table in $crossjoin and $expand?

    • Or should I use something like DRN2 directly (if that’s a separate entity set)?

  2. What is the correct $expand structure to include both ODRN and Depreciation Lines in one query?

  3. Could you please confirm the valid entity set names for both header and lines?
    I couldn’t find clear documentation showing whether DRN2 is an exposed collection or only accessible as a navigation property.

  4. If $crossjoin doesn't support navigation like ODRN/DRN2, what is the recommended pattern to retrieve header and line data in a single query?

entry.title: Re: Credit blocked orders with zero confirmed quantity to update exposure with open credit value

entry.title: Re: Advanced Intercompany Sales & Stock Transfer in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Hi,

currently there is no concrete plan when multistage ICo sales or multistage ICo stock transfer process in a multisystem environment is supported.

You can create a customer influence portal entry. Customer influence portal entries with many votes have an increased priority in our S/4 HANA portfolio.

Best regards,
Bernd

entry.title: COST CENTER UPDATE NOT POSSIBLE IN BADIs 2645,0061 and 0081 -cloud public edition- SAP BRIM FI-CA
entry.content:
Due to the SAP limitations to assign the CO assigment (cokey) in the posting area 2610 (it should be assigned line by line and the business requires to have thousand of different combinations for the assigment) I'm trying to update the cost center (Kostl) when the Posting FI-CA lines are created using the changeable structures that SAP allows to use in different BADis. 

The BADi FKK_EVENT_2645 is used to to fill or change customer-specific fields of the invoicing document and the related (not yet posted) posting documents and some certain standard fields. As the KOSTL is in the changeable structure FKKOP_GNF_T. Checking the result with a trace it seems like the field is getting updated but after this event, it is blanked out in any place of the standard code.

Same behavior when we tried to change the Cost center information using the contract accounting BADis FKK_EVENT_0061 and FKK_EVENT_0081.

Does anyone change/substitute the cost center value when the FI-CA document is created in SAP Public cloud edition? 

Thanks

@FICAX @FICO @FICA #FICA #FICAX #FICO #BRIM #CIBRIM

entry.title: Need Help Mapping Tax Entries to Supplier Invoice Items–Issue in Developing Purchase Register Report
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

We are in the process of developing a custom Purchase Register report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, and are encountering several challenges in retrieving accurate tax information at the invoice item level. Despite leveraging standard CDS views, we are unable to establish a reliable linkage between tax entries and their corresponding document items—which is critical for our reporting requirements.

Purpose of the Requirement
The goal is to build a Purchase Register report that provides a consolidated view of:

  • Supplier invoice line items

  • Tax amounts (eligible and ineligible)

  • Freight and asset item taxes

  • Proper item-wise tax segregation and traceability

This report is essential for GST compliance, input tax credit (ITC) auditability, and monthly financial reporting. However, the current limitations in CDS views are hindering this development.

Key Issues Faced

Case 1: Ineligible Tax – Missing Item-Level Field

  • No dedicated item-level field exists for capturing ineligible tax amounts.

  • The available tax CDS views do not return these tax entries, making it difficult to retrieve or calculate the correct tax per invoice item.

Case 2: Freight as a Separate Line Item

  • When freight is posted separately, the tax CDS views do not clearly map the freight tax to the original invoice item.

  • Since both the invoice and freight line may share the same item number, it's impossible to distinguish the tax details per line.

Case 4 & 5: Asset Item – Tax Posting Per Quantity

  • For asset purchases, tax is posted per quantity (e.g., 3 units = 3 tax lines).

  • This leads to a mismatch between item numbers of the invoice and the tax entries.

  • As a result, we cannot reliably link each tax entry to the correct item in the billing document, breaking traceability and affecting report accuracy.

CDS Views Evaluated

We have tried the following:

  • I_OperationalAcctgDocItem
    Used to retrieve item-level data for supplier invoices, but lacks direct tax linkage.

  • I_SupplierInvoiceTaxAPI01
    Evaluated, but it does not provide the expected item-level breakdown or association to the correct invoice lines.

Help Needed From Community

We are looking for your expert suggestions on:

  • Any alternate CDS views that offer more granular linkage between invoice item and tax lines.

  • Recommended approaches or best practices to model or join tax data effectively for such scenarios.

  • Relevant SAP Notes, documentation, or workarounds followed in Public Cloud environments.

Any support, guidance, or shared experiences would be greatly appreciated to help us unblock this critical development.

Thank you in advance!

Kind regards,
Tasneem Ahmad Karimi

Let me know if you'd like a version with your company name, SAP tenant ID, or further formatting.

entry.title: Re: Change Activation Status of Sales Condition Contract...
entry.content:
Hi,

You can consider the following:

Standard Approach

  1. Lock the Contract: Since the contract is in ‘active’ status, you need to first lock the contract. This action will enable the ‘Request Approval’ button, allowing you to trigger the approval workflow again.

  2. Use the Manage Workflows for Condition Contracts App: Workflows for Sales Rebate Processing This app allows you to manage workflows related to condition contracts, including releasing condition contracts for settlement. You can define the conditions under which the workflow should be restarted.

Development Approach

  1. Custom Logic for Restarting Workflow: You can create a custom implementation using the BAdI ‘Definition of Conditions to Restart Workflow Workflows for Settlement Management in Purchase Contracts’. This allows you to define specific conditions under which the workflow should be restarted when changes are made to the contract.

  2. Custom Logic App: Use the Custom Logic app to implement your own rules for restarting the workflow based on changes made to the contract.

Best regards, Dequan Xu

entry.title: Re: Hard Stop User to Start the Operation in POD if Not C...
entry.content:
Hi,

our customer requires that to perform a "Start" there should be always a labor in user logged into the operation.

So we attached on the START button two plugin:

  • labor in plugin
  • Custom PPD for Start

Inside the custom PPD we are checking if there is a timerecord opened for that operation with date end equal to null. If not, signoff on the operation.

Also, I found out from Manoel Costa’s latest blog post on uncollected checklist parameters that if, in your POD button actions, you have for example three objects, and in the middle you insert a PPD that ends with an 'error end', this can affect the execution of the following plugins as well. I haven’t tested it myself yet, but according to MC’s blog, it works.

entry.title: Re: Cloud Transport Management retention period over 30 days
entry.content:
Hi Daniel,

Daily cleanup only applies to transport requests that reach a final status - such as "Deleted," "Error," "Skipped," "Successful," or "Warning". This means that any transport request with a final status will be cleaned up based on the configured file retention period (default: 30 days): Here, only the file is deleted, while any metadata will be still available.

Transport requests with non-final statuses—such as "Fatal," "Initial," "Repeatable," or "Running" - are not subject to this cleanup.

Therefore, if you perform deployments from DEV -> QA -> PROD, there is no risk as long as the transport does not remain in one of the final statuses for more than 30 days + once a transport reaches a node, the first status it receives is "initial" anyway.

Hope this helps,

Sven

entry.title: Re: Change Activation Status of Sales Condition Contract with Released Status
entry.content: Hi there, I completely understand the challenge — it's important for compliance and accuracy that any changes post-release are re-approved properly. From what you've described, the main blocker is the 'active' status of the contract, which disables the "Request Approval" button. In the standard public cloud setup, SAP enforces strict status-based controls, so unfortunately, there is no standard functionality to revert the activation status once a condition contract is released. However, here are a few suggestions: Use a change reason trigger: Consider enhancing your workflow logic to trigger approval based on key field changes, not just status. You could do this via in-app extensibility if your system allows tracking such changes. Custom logic via BAdIs or Developer Extensibility: If you're on SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud with developer extensibility enabled, you could create a custom logic (e.g., using RAP action or side-by-side extension) that: Temporarily locks the contract, Flags it for re-approval, Or even automates the “unlock + retrigger approval” steps. Raise an SAP Idea or Incident: Since you're on Public Cloud, options are limited compared to on-prem. If this is a recurring business need, I recommend submitting this as an improvement request through the SAP Influence Portal, or contacting SAP Support to confirm if there's any undocumented workaround. In the meantime, the manual workaround you mentioned (lock > retrigger approval) might be the only viable approach. Let me know if you're using Manage Sales Condition Contracts Fiori App or another method — I might be able to share more specific guidance.

entry.title: Selective Data Transition: Functional Advantages of Selective Migration
entry.content:
Beyond Migration: Unlocking Business Transformation with Selective Data Transition

Many companies today face the challenge of transitioning their complex ERP landscapes to SAP S/4HANA. The pressure is on to not only modernize technically but also to position themselves functionally for the future. While traditional approaches often emphasize a purely technical migration, Selective Data Transition (SDT) offers a broader perspective: it enables companies to embed functional, organizational, and process improvements directly into the transformation without sacrificing valuable data or historical insights.

 

Shaping Transformation Instead of Just Migrating

At its core, Selective Data Transition is not simply about selective data migration. The migration approach becomes a strategic lever to actively shape the future ERP system. Companies are no longer bound to a one-to-one copy of their legacy systems. Instead, they can modernize processes, consolidate system landscapes, and integrate new functionalities – all with purpose and direction.

This is particularly valuable for organizations with highly customized and heterogeneous ERP environments. SDT provides the opportunity to shed legacy burdens while preserving historical knowledge – but only where it is truly needed.

 

Functional Realignment Within the Target System

One of SDT’s key strengths lies in the ability to implement functional innovations as part of the transformation, rather than delaying them until after go-live. From the outset, companies can tailor their new system to meet tomorrow’s business needs. Practical examples include:

  • Universal Journal: Consolidates all financial data into one harmonized structure. This allows consistent reporting, simplifies controlling, and significantly enhances external financial disclosures.
  • Business Partner Concept: Replaces separate customer and vendor master data with a unified business partner view, improving data governance, compliance, and end-to-end process integration.
  • Logistics Enhancements: Features like Advanced ATP (for more accurate delivery date commitments) or Embedded EWM (for modern warehouse management) can be selectively implemented during the transition.
  • Modern Reporting: Relevant data can be migrated in a structured way and integrated directly into advanced analytics tools, ensuring data quality, real-time access, and media-free reporting processes.

The crucial point: these innovations don’t need to be rolled out across the entire system. They can be implemented selectively where they create tangible value – in data-heavy areas, specific business units, or as part of pilot initiatives. Relevant historical data can also be transferred selectively to avoid disruptions in information flow. In this way, SDT becomes a catalyst for innovation, process modernization, and functional excellence in the new ERP environment.

 

Targeted and Flexible Data Migration

Beyond functional realignment, SDT offers a high level of flexibility on the data side. Companies maintain full control over which data to migrate, from which sources, and to what level of detail.

This means not everything is carried over, only what is relevant to the future system is migrated.

Examples include:

  • Selective migration of clients, company codes, or plants, for instance, in carve-outs or acquisitions.
  • Restructuring of organizational units, allowing alignment with future governance models or regional business needs.
  • Legacy data archiving: only the necessary data is transferred into the new system. This keeps the target system lean, reduces maintenance costs, and simplifies operations.

Even for transactional documents, historical records, or configuration settings, a selective approach is key: Which periods should be retained? Which document types are still relevant? Which customizations must be carried over and which should be redesigned or retired?

The result: a clean, harmonized target system, free of unnecessary legacy data but still compliant with all legal, regulatory, and business requirements, striking an ideal balance between efficiency, compliance, and transparency.

 

A Structured Approach with a Clear Target Picture

The success of a Selective Data Transition relies heavily on a clearly defined target picture and a robust methodology. SDT is not a plug-and-play solution, it is a strategically planned transformation process.

At the beginning of the selective migration planning stands one essential question: What should the future ERP system look like? To answer this question, further considerations are required, including:

  • Which processes should be standardized?
  • Which systems should be harmonized?
  • What data is truly relevant?
  • What functional improvements should be realized?

Based on this vision, a detailed analysis of the current landscape is conducted. This includes systems, processes, data quality, and custom developments. Often, the greatest challenge lies not in the technology itself, but in the lack of transparency.

Interactive workshops involving business and IT stakeholders ensure that the transformation is shaped collaboratively. This ensures that technical feasibility, business requirements, and strategic goals are fully aligned. Potential risks such as data inconsistencies, integration issues, or functional dependencies, can thus be identified early and addressed proactively.

 

SDT as a Key to Functional Excellence

Selective Data Transition is far more than just an alternative migration approach. It is a powerful strategic enabler for realizing functional benefits, modernizing processes, and taking an active role in shaping the transformation journey. Choosing SDT means more than adopting SAP S/4HANA. It means investing in a smarter, leaner, and future-ready version of your ERP system. For organizations that want to shape change rather than merely manage it, SDT is the ideal path forward into a digitally empowered future.

Discover more: Watch the full webinar recording now and learn how Selective Data Transition enables not just a technical migration – but transformation with real business impact.

entry.title: XSA Application UAA authentication possibilities?
entry.content:
I'm evaluating a few different authentication methods mentioned in:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_HANA_PLATFORM/4505d0bdaf4948449b7f7379d24d0f0d/a004e4fb650c480f9beee556295f21af.html?locale=en-US

I successfully created and configured a MTA application to work with OAuth password grant as described here:

https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-members/how-to-get-an-access-token-from-the-xsuaa-service-for-external-api-accesses/bc-p/13359519

But the documentation also mentions:

  • JSON Web Tokens (JWT)

  • X.509 client certificates

  • Kerberos(Spnego)

I've tested sending a HTTP request with grant_type urn:ietf:params:oauth:grant-type:jwt-bearer to https://hxehost:39032/uaa-security/oauth/token and it seems to recognize the grant type, but how are the required credentials configured?

I'm struggling to find documentation on setting up the authentication methods mentioned above in my project. Any help with this would be appreciated.

entry.title: is there any way to provide the expense Gl in the AP invoice screen instead of Purchase order screen
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

For Service/subcontract/non-stock PO, we need to select the respective expense Gl in the PO, but my client is stating, they can't provide a specific expense GL account there. There are lots of service expenses or subcontract expenses available there, and they are saying they can't teach that to procurement. So, is there any way to provide expense Gl in the AP invoice screen while referring to the PO?

My resolution:

1. If you think the procurement team will select the wrong GL, we can create different valuation classes for each service/subcontract/non-stock, and they can select the respective materials in the PO, and the GL account will come automatically.

2. We can create a control account there, and for any type of Subcontract/service/Non-stock, it will be selected.  and in the invoice screen you can reverse that.

GRN:

Control acc Dr

GR/IR Cr

AP invoice:

Supplier Cr

GR/IR Dr

control acc Cr

expense Acc Dr

is there any alternative that I can use?

entry.title: SAP DRC NFe outbound - Erro de CERTIFICADO
entry.content:
Olá pessoal!

Em alguns momentos tenho tido mensagem de erro no retorno de envio da NFe para SEFAZ.
A mensagem refere a certificado. Veja abaixo:

HTTP 400 - solicitação inválida.
Could not load certificate.

Ocorre de forma esporádica, ou seja, consigo emitir e aprovar várias notas mas por vezes a mensagem acima aparece. Se eu envio novamente, dá certo e é aprovada.

Estamos mo SAP S/4 HANA 2023 release 108 e utilizando o SAP DRC NFe outbound.
Alguém já passou por isto  e pode contribuir na solução?

entry.title: Re: Data Action : Allocating cost From one Cost Center to...
entry.content:
This is working now :

VARIABLEMEMBER #TOTAL_CUSTOMER OF [d/ZFCUSTOMER]
VARIABLEMEMBER #CUST OF [d/ZFCUSTOMER]
VARIABLEMEMBER #COSTCENTRE OF [d/ZFCOSTCENTER]
VARIABLEMEMBER #PROFITCENTRE OF [d/ZFPROFITCTR]
VARIABLEMEMBER #PLANT OF [d/ZFPLANT]
VARIABLEMEMBER #GL OF [d/ZFGLACCOUNT]

 

DATA([d/ZFCOSTCENTER]=#COSTCENTRE,[d/ZFPROFITCTR]=#PROFITCENTRE,[d/ZFPLANT]=#PLANT,[d/Measures]="ZFKDEPCRIFRS") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="ZFKDEPCRIFRS",[d/ZFCUSTOMER]="#")


DATA([d/ZFGLACCOUNT] = #GL, [d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA", [d/ZFGLACCOUNT] = "#")
DATA([d/Measures] = "ZFKDEPCRIFRS", [d/ZFCUSTOMER] = #CUST) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "ZFKDEPCRIFRS")


// // Copying Amount to all customers
DATA([d/Measures] = "ZFKDEPCRIFRS") = (RESULTLOOKUP([d/ZFGLACCOUNT] = #GL, [d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA") * 0 + 1 ) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/ZFCOSTCENTER]=#COSTCENTRE,[d/ZFPROFITCTR]=#PROFITCENTRE,[d/ZFPLANT]=#PLANT,[d/Measures]="ZFKDEPCRIFRS")


// // Copying Area to all customers
DATA([d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/ZFGLACCOUNT] = #GL, [d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA") * ( RESULTLOOKUP([d/ZFCOSTCENTER]=#COSTCENTRE,[d/ZFPROFITCTR]=#PROFITCENTRE,[d/ZFPLANT]=#PLANT,[d/Measures]="ZFKDEPCRIFRS") * 0 + 1 )
// // Calculating Allocated Cost in ratio of Area against all customers
DATA([d/ZFCUSTOMER] = #TOTAL_CUSTOMER, [d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA",[d/ZFGLACCOUNT]="#",[d/ZFCOSTCENTER]=#COSTCENTRE,[d/ZFPLANT]=#PLANT,[d/ZFPROFITCTR]=#PROFITCENTRE) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA",[d/ZFGLACCOUNT]="#")

DATA([d/Measures] = "ZFALLOCATEDCOST") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA") / RESULTLOOKUP([d/ZFCUSTOMER] = #TOTAL_CUSTOMER, [d/Measures] = "ZFKAREA",[d/ZFGLACCOUNT]="#",[d/ZFCOSTCENTER]=#COSTCENTRE,[d/ZFPLANT]=#PLANT,[d/ZFPROFITCTR]=#PROFITCENTRE) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "ZFKDEPCRIFRS")

// //Reversing the Original Amount

DATA([d/Measures] = "ZFKDEPCRIFRS") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures] = "ZFKDEPCRIFRS") *-1 // This will be a problem if allocation is run in iterations as you will lose original amount

DATA([d/Measures]="ZFALLOCATEDCOST", [d/ZFCUSTOMER]="#") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="ZFKDEPCRIFRS",[d/ZFCUSTOMER]="#")


DELETE ([d/ZFGLACCOUNT] = "#" )

entry.title: Customer Engagement Initiative: "Q2C Value Metrics" App
entry.content:
Unlocking Your Q2C Potential: Introducing the "Q2C Value Metrics" App!

 

Hey everyone,

Are you curious about how efficiently your daily tasks are contributing to your company's success? Do you ever wonder if there's a better, faster way to get things done within our S/4HANA public cloud edition Quote-to-Cash (Q2C) processes?

Good news! Our product management team is working on something designed just for you, the ground-level users who make our Q2C processes hum. We're excited to announce an upcoming initiative to investigate a potential "Q2C Value Metrics" app, and we want your input from the very beginning!

 

What's This All About?

 

Our goal with the "Q2C Value Metrics" app is to give you direct visibility into the efficiency and impact of your work. Think of it as a personalized dashboard that highlights the tangible value you're creating.

For the initial release (our Minimum Viable Product or MVP), we're focusing on key metrics that we believe will resonate immediately:

  • Automation Rate: We'd like to measure and report on key automation metrics across the Q2C cycle. e.g. Invoicing Automation: What percentage of invoices were successfully created and posted without any manual intervention. This metric is a direct indicator of smooth, error-free processing, and we believe it's a great starting point for understanding process health. We'd be thrilled to learn what other automation avenues you currently are or would like to focus on.
  • We would also be interested in knowing other key business value metrics you would be interested in such as (but not limited to) the following.
    • Day Sales Outstanding (DSO): the average number of days it takes your business to collect payments after a sale. It's a quick way to check how well you're managing your accounts receivable and if your cash flow is as healthy as it could be.
    • Quote Conversion Rate: the percentage of your sales quotes or proposals that actually get accepted and become an order. This helps you see how effective your sales team is at closing deals and if your pricing or proposals are hitting the mark.

 

Why Should You Care?

 

You might be thinking, "That sounds interesting, but how does this help me?" Here's how:

  • See Your Impact: Directly observe how your daily efforts contribute to overall process efficiency.
  • Identify Opportunities: Gain insights into areas where you or your team can become even more productive.
  • Be a Part of the Future: Your feedback will be crucial in shaping the evolution of this app.

 

What's Next for the "Q2C Value Metrics" App?

 

The MVP is just the beginning! Once we have these core metrics in place and gather your valuable feedback, we envision a future where:

  • Benchmarking Against Customers: You'll be able to anonymously compare your team's performance against industry benchmarks and other customers, giving you a clearer picture of potential improvement areas.
  • Identifying Improvement Opportunities: With this data, you'll be empowered to pinpoint bottlenecks, suggest process enhancements, and drive positive change within your Q2C workflows.
  • Expanding Key Metrics: We plan to continuously expand the app to include a wider range of key Q2C metrics that matter most to you and your daily operations.

 

We Want to Hear From You!

 

Your insights are invaluable. We want to understand what business value metrics make the most sense for you, the everyday users of our S/4HANA public cloud. Your perspectives will directly influence the development and evolution of this app.

Are you excited about the idea of tracking your Q2C efficiency? Do these initial metrics resonate with you? What other metrics would you find most helpful in your day-to-day work?

We'd love to discuss this further with you. Please sign up under our campaign to share your thoughts and help us build an app that truly empowers you!

entry.title: Re: Sale price record VK11 upto 5 decimals
entry.content:
Yes changing the decimal places of an existing currency like EUR is not recommended once postings exist in the system, Can lead to data inconsistencies, rounding errors, and reconciliation issues in FI and SD and may affect historical documents, reports, and open items. Rigorous testing is mandatory in this case. Have a look at other SAP notes 137626 and 434349.

In fact, it is also good to go with your idea to add a custom column for 5-digit price input, let the system auto-convert to 2-decimal pricing per 10PC or 100PC, which is both practical and user-friendly. It avoids currency changes and reduces manual errors.

entry.title: @cap/cds-dk transitive dependency vulnerability unable to be resolved
entry.content:
I am using the direct dependency @cap/cds-dk in my package.json defined as version 9.1.1 (Currently the latest). The project has a vulnerability introduced by form-data, which is a transitive dependency.
npm ls form-data:

 

├─┬ @SAP/cds-dk@9.1.1
│ └─┬ axios@1.10.0
│   └── form-data@4.0.3

 

I found 2 possible solutions of the problem: upgrade axios to 1.11.0 or form-data to 4.0.4.
Unfortunately all the ways that I tried to do this are not working. Here is what I tried:

Try 1 - overrides:

I tried all of those to be added to my package.json, but axios keeps being not overriden and stays at version 1.10.0, respectively form-data stays at version 4.0.3.

 

  "overrides": {
    "@sap/cds-dk": {
      "axios": "^1.11.0"
    }
  },

 

 

 

  "overrides": {
      "axios": "^1.11.0"
  },

 

 

 

  "overrides": {
      "form-data": "4.0.4"
  },

 

 



Try 2 - resolutions:
I also tried using resolutions, but it did not work as well.

Analysis:
I analyzed the steps that npm does to provide the form-data dependency after my override, and the results are similar whether I try to override axios or form-data:

 

npm explain form-data
form-data@4.0.3 dev
node_modules/@sap/cds-dk/node_modules/form-data
  form-data@"^4.0.0" from axios@1.10.0
  node_modules/@sap/cds-dk/node_modules/axios
    overridden axios@"1.11.0" (was "^1") from @SAP/cds-dk@9.1.1
    node_modules/@sap/cds-dk
      dev @SAP/cds-dk@"9.1.1" from the root project

 

I have tried other similar methods as well, but all of them do not override the dependency.

Am I missing something, or is it a possible solution that @SAP/cds-dk updates the axios dependency to 1.11.0?

entry.title: Re: is there any way to provide the expense Gl in the AP...
entry.content:
Some alternatives to automate or defer GL account selection are

  • in OMQW, you can map material groups to valuation classes, which then drive GL account determination via OBYC. This works even for non-stock or service materials without an accounting view. Procurement only needs to select the correct material group, not the GL account.
  • You can configure account assignment categories (e.g., K for cost center, F for order) to default specific GL accounts. This reduces manual entry and ensures consistency across similar purchases.

entry.title: Re: Hi , I'm getting below idoc error
entry.content:
Possible root causes for this error are

  • Field status mismatch such that the GL account 3598*** might have a field (like cost center, tax code, etc.) set as required, but the IDoc doesn’t supply it. This causes SAP expecting input that isn’t available in the batch session
  • If the GL account has the “Supplement for automatic postings” flag (SKB1-XNKON) set, SAP may prompt for manual input during posting—even in background. This is a known cause of this error
  • The field status group assigned to the GL account may require fields that aren’t populated by the IDoc.
  • If the billing document is in one currency and the GL account expects another, rounding differences can cause SAP to present an unexpected screen

What you can do is

  • check in fs00 for GL 3598***, the field status group and ensure no fields are marked as “required” unless they’re always supplied by the IDoc.
  • In table SKB1, check if the “Supplement for automatic postings” flag is set for this GL. If yes, consider disabling it if manual supplementation isn’t needed.
  • Use WE02 or WE19 to inspect the IDoc. Confirm that the segment for GL 3598*** includes all required fields (e.g., amount, cost object, tax code).

entry.title: Building a Custom Digital Manufacturing POD Plugin — The New Easy Way
entry.content:
Introduction

This post is an updated guide to my original blog on simplifying the creation of SAP Digital Manufacturing (DM) POD plugins.

Back then, I introduced a Yeoman-based tool that scaffolded a SAP DM view plugin to accelerate development. However, since that release, the POD framework has evolved:

  • POD 1.0: Plugin is bundled in an MTAR file and deployed into Cloud Foundry. CORS configuration is required.
  • POD 1.1 (introduced in release 2502): Plugin is loaded directly into SAP DM via the POD Designer as a ZIP file. No CORS configuration needed.
  • POD 2.0 (coming soon): A completely new framework with different plugin requirements.

Given these developments—and the need for additional features like multi-language support, 3rd party library integration, and auto-updates—the Yeoman tool no longer made sense.

Introducing the New Approach

We now have a Visual Studio Code (VSCode) / SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) extension that makes plugin creation significantly easier, more flexible, and future-ready.

Installation

Step 1: Locate the Extension

In VSCode or BAS:

  • Open the Extensions pane.

 You may see a message if this is the first time you have installed an Extension, click OK to agree.

 

  • Search for SAP DM POD.

 

  • Click on the extension and press Install.

 

📌Note:

  • Ensure you're using VSCode version 1.99.3 or later (BAS is currently based on 1.99.3).
  • Enable Auto Update to receive future enhancements.

Step 2: Handle BAS Warnings

If you're using BAS, you may see:

  • A trust prompt → Click Trust Publisher & Install

 

  • A signature warning → Click Install Anyway (Don’t Verify Signature)

 

Once installed, you’ll see the Disable and Uninstall options enabled.

 

 

Extension Commands

This extension adds two commands:

  1. Create SAP DM POD Plugin
  2. ZIP all files in current workspace

Run them via:

  • Ctrl + Shift + P, or
  • Click the command palette and search.

 

Creating a Plugin

Step 1: Prepare a Workspace

Before generating a plugin, create a folder (workspace) where the files will be placed. Extensions cannot create folders due to security restrictions.

Step 2: Launch the Generator

Use the command "Create SAP DM POD Plugin". The GUI will appear, offering multiple configuration options.

 

 

Generator Options Explained

🔹Select POD Version

  • POD 1.0: Requires MTAR packaging and CORS setup (legacy, being phased out).
  • POD 1.1: Recommended. Plugin is deployed as a ZIP file with no CORS config needed.

⚠️POD 2.0 is expected to enter beta in late 2025, with GA in early 2026.

🔹Select POD Type

  • Currently supports View Plugins (Execution Plugins coming soon).

🔹Plugin Name

  • Technical identifier (lowercase only, no numbers/special characters).

🔹POD Designer Name

  • Friendly display name shown in the POD Designer. Can include numbers, spaces, and uppercase letters.

🔹Version & Namespace

  • Define your plugin’s version and namespace.

🔹Hostname (only for POD 1.0)

  • Used for CORS configuration. Not applicable for POD 1.1.

🔹Misc Options

  • Toggle optional features .

🔹3rd Party Libraries

Select popular libraries to include (e.g., Lodash, date-fns). These will be auto-added to your manifest.json.

🔹Language Support

Choose supported locales. The generator will:

  • Create i18n files.
  • Set supportedLocales in manifest.json.

Example: Creating and Deploying a POD 1.1 Plugin

Let’s create a plugin with the following:

  • Plugin Name: blogplugin
  • POD Designer Name: Blog Plugin
  • Type: View plugin
  • POD Types Supported: Operation and Workcenter
  • 3rd Party Libraries: MQTT
  • Language Support: English, Spanish and Japanese

 

  • Launch the generator and make the selections.

 

  • Click Create.
  • The extension scaffolds the entire plugin structure.

 

The plugin is now ready for you to add your own functionality but as it already has some basic functionality it can be deployed straight away.

Deploying the Plugin

  1. Run the command: "ZIP all files in current workspace"
    → This generates a ZIP file named after your plugin.
  2. In BAS: Right-click the ZIP and select Download to get it locally, In VSCode: It's already saved locally.
  3. Open SAP DM > POD Designer.
    • Navigate to the EXTENSIONS tab.
    • Click Create.
    • Upload your ZIP.
    • Enter the appropriate name and namespace (plugin namespace + plugin name).

 

✅Your plugin is now available in the POD Designer.

 

 

Conclusion

This new extension-driven method streamlines the entire POD plugin development experience—removing the need for CORS, MTAR complexity, and manual library setup.

With POD 1.1 now the standard, and POD 2.0 on the horizon, this tool ensures you're ready for the future of SAP Digital Manufacturing.

entry.title: Re: The SAP BW Data Product Generator for SAP Business Data Cloud
entry.content:
Hi Christof,

Thank you for the great blog post—really insightful!

I was wondering if there are any plans for SAP BDC to support direct data loading from BW to the BDC object store, rather than relying on Queries as InfoProviders. As you know, using Queries as InfoProviders introduces several limitations, which can make it quite challenging to transition BW data products into BDC.

In BW, the Query often represents the final data product, complete with all necessary business logic and semantics. If we have to move data from InfoProviders instead, it seems we would need to reimplement those semantics again in SAP Datasphere, which adds complexity.

Would love to hear your thoughts on this.

Best regards,
Arvind

entry.title: Re: Storage Location as MRP area
entry.content:
It could be due to

  • MD04 defaults to plant-level view unless you explicitly select the MRP Area. To see PRs for the storage location MRP Area, you must run MD04 using the MRP Area code, not just the plant.
  • In the material master, under MRP1, ensure the MRP Area assignment is active and not just listed. Also confirm that the planning type is set correctly (e.g., PD for MRP).
  • If the storage location in the sales order shipping tab doesn’t match the one defined in the MRP Area, the system may plan at the plant level instead.

What you can do is use transaction MD04, enter the MRP Area code instead of just the plant. This will show PRs and requirements specific to that storage location.

entry.title: An integrated view on Inbound Container Transport
entry.content:
Not too long ago, a client (a big shipper) lamented to me that it was so difficult to gain insight into the progress of the execution of procurement processes. When he ordered a container full of goods, he would, at best, receive a shipping notification with a container number and then have to search through the systems of various transporters to locate his cargo. In the worst case, he wouldn't hear anything more, and the goods would suddenly appear at the door of his warehouse. Or his container would be sitting in the port without his knowledge, and he would have to pay a significant amount in detention costs.

In my opinion, the greatest strength of SAP is not just the variety of features it offers to support business processes, but its ability to provide integrated process information. In the above case, this means that the purchaser should be able to track the progress and have all relevant of his of his shipment based on his purchase order number. And the transportation planner should be able to plan and communicate his cargo with the carrier using unique freight order numbers.

To demonstrate to this client that this is no longer futuristic, we put together the following demo, utilizing SAP S/4HANA Transportation Management (TM) and SAP Business Network for Freight Collaboration (FC), and SAP Business Network for Global Track and Trace (GTT), to show how it can support an inbound container transport from China to Europe.

This scenario begins with the creation of a Purchase Order with incoterms FOB at port of loading. In this case, the shipper plans and organizes its sea transport from the port of loading, (Guangzhou South China Oceangate), to the port of destination (Rotterdam), and from there, the road transport to the warehouse in Saarbrucken using SAP Transportation Management.

Based on the expected delivery date, the ocean transport is planned by selecting a departure/voyage from an ocean schedule. The freight booking is sent from SAP TM to the ocean carrier using the BN for FC network. Once confirmed by the ocean carrier, the transportation planner receives the result back in SAP TM

Based on the Freight booking, the progress of the execution process can be tracked in SAP GTT using updates from the ocean carrier or the visibility provider. To make this process more clear, we built a small low code tool for it in SAP Build, the GTT route simulator. I will elaborate on this in a later blog, but this is what it produces:

When the container is delivered to the port of Rotterdam, it is picked up by the road transporter, who confirms the order in FC, makes a dock appointment for the warehouse, and reports events in FC reporting. Arrival at the warehouse is registered in the gate-in process, after which the truck is assigned a dock, and the unloading and goods receipt take place. In the demo, this happens using Advanced Shipping & Receiving.

After the transport is completed, both the ocean carrier and the road carrier submit their invoices via BN for FC. If there are disputes, these are resolved through communication in BN for FC before a freight settlement document is created in Transportation Management, ensuring that the cumbersome process of PO reversal does not have to be initiated. The entire logistical process, from the FCL Purchase Order to the payment of the transporters, is transparent and integrated:

When I presented the demo to the client, one of the purchasers sighed, "It's so beautiful, I could almost cry." It was one of my more enjoyable days as a consultant.

entry.title: Re: Badi FIN_ACDOC_ITEM_VALIDATION does not have necessar...
entry.content:
Hi Aish26

Have you checked the BADI

FINS_PAYT_REQ_DETERMINATION (payment request determination) 

Help link: App Extensibility: Free Form Payments

"Use

This enhancement option determines how a custom field should interact with other fields on a payment request master data record. It enables you to assign specific values to other fields when the user selects or modifies your custom field.

Only one implementation is allowed.

Parameters:

  • C_PAYMENT_REQUEST – Payment request.
  • C_CHANGED_FIELDS – Names of the fields to update in C_PAYMENT_REQUEST.
  • C_MESSAGES – Table with the messages to be displayed when the fields are updated."

It has house bank and account among other fields in the Changing Parameters

Thank you

Jerry

entry.title: Recordando palestras do SIT Joinville
entry.content:
Joinville já contou com eventos importantes da Comunidade SAP como o SITJOI 2015 e 2016, e também um Codejam. 

Para quem deseja ver ou rever algumas apresentações que foram gravadas seguem abaixo os links.

entry.title: Re: Horizon Theme and Templates for Stories in SAP Analytics Cloud
entry.content:
Greetings @felixjonathanmueller

it's very good to see that the general dark theme was taken into account.
The next question is, will there be an automatic adaptation between light / dark theme based on time or the OS preferences? Like when the operating system switches to dark mode (or the browser) in the evening, the SAC does too. 

Also, there are still a few bugs in the design, like the input control active press, which seems to still have the old SAC blue (in dark and light mode). The CSS command for the active / hover is in general not exposed, would be great to have it. 

Also the floating menu seems to miss a bit of contrast. I like that it is less blue, but it merges with the background. I think it would help to have a tint of gray in it.

Old: 

Light:

Dark:

I noticed other minor bugs from the version 1.0.4 are already fixed. I'm really looking forward for Q4 and the new design <3.

entry.title: Re: CopyStep using Advanced Formula Step
entry.content:
Try this. Add this to the end of my previous code

//Copying to 2027

FOREACH [d/Date]

DATA([d/Date]=NEXT(12))=RESULTLOOKUP()

ENDFOR

entry.title: Re: How to know SAP license usage of my company?
entry.content:
You can see an overview of license consumption in SAP4Me in the Customer Insights Dashboard (CID). The CID is located at Home/Reporting/Customer Insights Dashboard >> License Consumption. This view allows you to see consumption at the metric measurement level (e.g. number of form requests). For authorization information to access CID, see KBA 3336856.

Customer Insights Dashboard on the SAP Support Portal

SAP Enterprise Support 

(opens in new tab)

entry.title: Personalized Recommendations LMS: Need more clarity
entry.content:
I want to know more about this feature.

Personalized Recommendations on the New Learning Home Page | SAP Help Portal

In this it says "It includes their profile information, growth portfolio attributes, and their system interactions and activities."

What it means by Profile information and System Interactions? Will it cover all the modules to suggest courses?

and can you explain the interactions? what acts as an interaction in the system? also what information it takes from the Profile?

Do we have a detailed explanation for this feature?

Also, if my interest is Ex. Leadership, will it show all the courses related to Leadership? or just some courses.?

 

Also,  Can we know why a particular course was recommended? is it because I searched for it, or completed a course or any other thing? Can a user know that?

SAP SuccessFactors Learning Machine Learning SAP Learning Solution

Thank you for this complete and up-to-date FAQ! I’ve got two additional questions regarding the licensing and transition to SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC):

  1. If I purchase SAP Datasphere and SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) now as a new customer - will I still be able to use the "old" licensing model without BDC until January 1, 2026, or has this changed already?

  2. For customers who already have licensed SAC and Datasphere without BDC, how long will they be able to continue using these tools without mandatory BDC enablement or conversion?

Thanks again for your great support and insights!

entry.title: Re: Replacemenet of V_WB2_VBRK_VBRP_1 CDS in Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi @serap_acar, 

If you want the billing documents considered at the time of Settlement creation for a specific contract, I would recommend to check the table WB2_D_BVDETAIL (used by transaction WB2R_BVDETAIL). 

If you want to retrieve the Billing documents and applying the selection criteria + period of the validity of the contract, indeed CDS view VWB2_VBRKVBRP_1 with data definition V_WB2_VBRK_VBRP_1 for 0S01 contract type or equivalent. 
You can also avoid all the struggle and use the Tcode WB2R_BUSVOL (Fiori tile ID = WB2R_BUSVOL - Display Business Volume - Condition Contracts). 

Regards, 
Gauthier Victor

entry.title: Need to learn skills essential steps for Concur Expense Professional Edition environment?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Getting Started with Concur Expense Professional Edition for Administrators learning journey.

Overview
This learning journey is designed to guide learners through the essential steps for successfully managing the Concur Expense Professional Edition environment as an administrator. It will help develop the skills necessary to ensure a smooth and compliant Expense management experience.

Learning objectives
By the end of this learning journey, learners will be able to:

  • Navigate and confidently manage various aspects of the Concur Expense Professional Edition environment as an administrator.
  • Oversee the entire expense report lifecycle — submission, review, approval, and audits to ensure adherence to company policies.
  • Provide practical support to end users.

Prerequisites
Essential:

  • Complete the Getting Started with Concur Expense for Customer Users learning journey before beginning this course.
Furthermore, learners should have
  • A basic understanding of their organization’s travel and expense policy.
  • Familiarity with general business processes related to expense management.
  • Access to a Concur Expense Professional Edition environment.
  • Basic knowledge of web-based administration tools.

Please post you question related to the digital learning Journey in the Q&A area. 
Our SAP Learning Experts will get back to you as soon as possible! We are here to support you. 

I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.
 
Kind regards
Margit

entry.title: SAPFPAYM not triggered automatically after F110 / Manage Automatic Payments
entry.content:
Hello SAP Experts,

I am facing an issue with Payment Medium Workbench (PMW) in S/4HANA.
When I run F110 (or Manage Automatic Payments), the payment run finishes successfully, payments are posted, and the payment advice notes are generated.

However, the payment medium file (DME) is not automatically created.
I always need to go to SE38 and run SAPFPAYM manually to generate the payment medium file.

In Manage Payment Media, the status of my items is usually "Downloaded", and I cannot change it to "To Be Generated".

Here are additional details:

  • Payment method is correctly assigned to DMEE format (e.g., FI_PAYMEDIUM_DMEE_CGI_05)

  • Program RFFOAVIS_FPAYM is assigned in the "Printout/Data Medium" tab of the payment method

  • In DME Administration (DMEEADMIN), I can see my file with "Data transmitted to external" checked

  • No DME file is found in AL11 unless I manually run SAPFPAYM

My question:

  • How can I configure F110 so that SAPFPAYM is automatically triggered during the payment run, without having to execute it manually?

  • Do I need to adjust the Payment Medium Workbench (PMW) selection variant, or maintain a missing link in the payment method customizing?

  • Could the status "Downloaded" in Manage Payment Media block the automatic generation?

Any advice or guidance on customizing steps to make SAPFPAYM run automatically after F110 would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: Re: Trading Partner within MM Subcontracting Consumption...
entry.content: Many thanks for your proposals. Unfortunatelly both do not work for us. Even we have different Material Number for the repaired item, the broken one is still in the BOM (for delivery out of the purchase order) and gets posted at goods receipt. Also the solution as non-valuated item does not work. These items are part of the valuated inventory. But again, thanks for your support.

entry.title: SAP Analytics Cloud for planning - Improve Advanced Formula for Date
entry.content:
Hi friends,

I'am using following Advanced formula. Does someone has a better and more slim way to express this:

DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(2,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(3,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(4,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(5,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(6,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(7,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(8,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(9,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(10,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(11,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)
DATA([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=NEXT(12,"MONTH",%Select_Date%))=RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]="Amount",[d/Date]=%Select_Date%)

Thanks in advance.

Kind regards,

Ismail
